definitions: becoming progressively smaller or more restricted in width or extent
gradually reducing the range, scope, or number of possibilities
examples: The narrowing path made hiking increasingly difficult
We entered through a narrowing tunnel into the cave
The narrowing options forced us to decide quickly
Their narrowing focus excluded important considerations

definitions: relating to or affecting the nose or nasal passages
produced by or passing through the nose in speech or sound
having an unpleasant whining quality reminiscent of speaking through the nose
examples: The nasal cavity filters air before reaching lungs
She suffered from chronic nasal congestion
French has several nasal vowel sounds
His nasal voice was distinctive on radio
Her nasal complaints irritated everyone at work
The singer's nasal tone ruined the performance

definitions: just coming into existence and beginning to display signs of future potential
in the process of being born or beginning to develop
examples: The nascent democracy faced many challenges ahead
Their nascent relationship showed promise despite obstacles
The nascent technology industry attracted venture capital
Scientists observed the nascent star forming in space

definitions: highly unpleasant to experience or deal with; disgusting or repugnant
behaving in a spiteful, unkind, or unpleasant way
dangerous, serious, or painful in nature or effect
morally offensive or indecent; involving unpleasant sexual elements
examples: The nasty smell made everyone leave the room
That medicine has a really nasty taste
She made nasty comments about his appearance
Don't be so nasty to your little brother
He suffered a nasty fall down the stairs
The infection turned into something nasty
They engaged in nasty behavior at the party
The website contained nasty adult content

definitions: relating to the time, process, or circumstances of birth
relating to the place or circumstances of one's birth
examples: The natal care unit provides specialized medical attention
Natal complications required immediate medical intervention
She returned to her natal village after retirement
His natal city honored him with a ceremony

definitions: relating to or characteristic of a nation or its government
owned, controlled, or funded by the federal government
extending throughout an entire nation; affecting all regions
examples: The national anthem played before the game
National security remains their top priority
The national parks attract millions of visitors annually
National healthcare provides coverage for all citizens
The story received national media coverage yesterday
It became a national crisis requiring immediate action

definitions: supporting or relating to nationalism as a political ideology
advocating for national independence or strong national identity
examples: The nationalist party won the recent election
Nationalist rhetoric dominated the political debate
Nationalist movements gained momentum across the region
The nationalist leader called for complete independence

definitions: showing excessive or aggressive patriotism or devotion to one's nation
characterized by or relating to nationalist political ideology
examples: His nationalistic fervor alienated international partners
The nationalistic propaganda increased during wartime
The nationalistic policies restricted foreign investment significantly
Their nationalistic approach ignored global cooperation needs

definitions: extending or occurring throughout an entire nation or country
examples: The company launched a nationwide advertising campaign
Nationwide protests erupted after the controversial decision
They conducted a nationwide survey of consumer preferences
The nationwide shortage affected millions of people

definitions: existing in or belonging to a place from earliest times
belonging to a person by birth or origin
innate, natural, or inherent rather than acquired
being an original inhabitant of a place or region
examples: Native plants thrive without special care here
The native wildlife faced threats from development
She speaks three languages including her native French
He returned to his native country after years
Her native intelligence helped her succeed academically
His native talent for music emerged early
The native peoples preserved their traditional customs
Native Americans inhabited this land for millennia

definitions: favoring the interests of native inhabitants over those of immigrants
relating to policies or movements opposing immigration
examples: The nativist movement gained support during economic downturns
Nativist rhetoric increased during the election campaign
The nativist policies restricted immigration quotas severely
Their nativist agenda alienated immigrant communities

definitions: smart and fashionable in dress or appearance; dapper
examples: He wore a natty suit to the interview
The natty dresser always attracted compliments
Her natty appearance impressed the board members
The shop sells natty clothing for young professionals

definitions: existing in or derived from nature; not made by humans
not involving anything artificial or synthetic; pure and unprocessed
having an innate talent or ability; coming easily without effort
normal, expected, or understandable in the circumstances
born of parents not married to each other; illegitimate
examples: The natural beauty of the landscape amazed visitors
Natural disasters can strike without warning
She prefers natural foods without preservatives
The fabric is made from natural fibers
He's a natural athlete with exceptional coordination
She has a natural gift for languages
It's natural to feel nervous before surgery
Their natural reaction was to defend themselves
The natural son inherited nothing from the estate
Natural children had fewer rights historically

definitions: having been granted citizenship of a country where not born
having become established in the wild in a region where not native
examples: The naturalised citizens voted for the first time
Her naturalised status allowed full participation
The naturalised plants spread throughout the region
These naturalised species now dominate local ecosystems

definitions: imitating nature or natural processes in a realistic and detailed way
based on the philosophical doctrine of naturalism
examples: The naturalistic paintings captured every detail perfectly
Her naturalistic acting style seemed completely authentic
The naturalistic approach excluded supernatural explanations entirely
Their naturalistic worldview shaped their research methods

definitions: having been granted citizenship of a country where not born
having become established in the wild in a region where not native
examples: The naturalized citizens celebrated their new status
As naturalized Americans, they could now vote
The naturalized species threatened native plant populations
These naturalized birds arrived decades ago

definitions: behaving badly or disobediently, especially of children
mildly indecent or sexually suggestive in a playful way
examples: The naughty children refused to go to bed
Don't be naughty or Santa won't bring presents
She gave him a naughty wink across the room
They shared naughty jokes at the party

definitions: relating to sailors, ships, or navigation at sea
examples: The nautical charts showed dangerous underwater rocks
His nautical experience made him an excellent captain
The restaurant featured nautical decor throughout
She studied nautical engineering at the academy

definitions: relating to a nation's navy or warships
examples: The naval base housed dozens of warships
Naval officers trained for months at sea
The naval battle changed the course of history
Their naval superiority ensured victory at sea

definitions: deep and wide enough to allow ships or boats to pass through
examples: The navigable river allowed trade to flourish inland
Only small boats find this creek navigable
The canal remained navigable throughout the dry season
Ice made the strait barely navigable in winter

definitions: relating to or used for the process of planning and following a route
examples: The navigational equipment failed during the storm
Modern navigational systems use satellite technology
Her navigational skills helped them reach safety
The navigational error led them miles off course

definitions: primitive, uncivilized, or intellectually backward in attitudes or behavior
relating to the extinct human species Homo neanderthalensis
examples: His neanderthal views on women shocked everyone
Their neanderthal approach to diplomacy failed miserably
The neanderthal skull showed distinctive features
Neanderthal DNA persists in modern human populations

definitions: tidy, orderly, and well-organized in appearance or arrangement
done with or demonstrating skill or efficiency
of alcoholic drinks served without water, ice, or mixer
excellent, impressive, or admirable in informal usage
examples: She kept her desk neat and organized always
The neat rows of vegetables pleased the gardener
That was a neat solution to the problem
He made a neat turn around the obstacle
He ordered his whiskey neat at the bar
She prefers her vodka neat rather than mixed
That's a really neat trick you just showed
What a neat idea for the party

definitions: vague, unclear, or ill-defined in form or character
having the form of a cloud or haze; lacking definite shape
examples: Their nebulous plans lacked concrete details
The agreement contained nebulous promises without specifics
A nebulous mist hung over the valley
The nebulous shape emerged from the darkness

definitions: required to be done, achieved, or present; needed and essential
inevitably resulting from the nature of things; unavoidable
examples: Bring only necessary items for the camping trip
The necessary paperwork must be completed first
War became a necessary consequence of their actions
Death is a necessary end for all living things

definitions: having a neck of a specified kind, usually in combination
examples: The long-necked giraffe reached the highest leaves
She wore a high-necked sweater for warmth
The narrow-necked bottle was hard to clean
Red-necked grebes nested by the lake

definitions: born with the name that follows; originally named before marriage
examples: Mrs. Smith, nee Johnson, attended the reunion
Sarah Williams, nee Brown, published her memoirs
The duchess, nee Mary Jones, visited her hometown
Jane Miller, nee Thompson, received the award

definitions: required, necessary, or wanted for a particular purpose
examples: The needed repairs will cost thousands of dollars
She provided much needed support during crisis
All needed documents must be submitted by Friday
The needed changes were implemented immediately

definitions: unnecessary and able to be avoided; serving no useful purpose
examples: His death was a needless tragedy
They caused needless suffering through their actions
Needless to say, we were disappointed
The needless complexity confused everyone involved

definitions: lacking the necessities of life; very poor and requiring help
requiring excessive emotional support or attention from others
examples: The charity helps needy families during winter
Needy children received free school supplies
Her needy boyfriend constantly demanded reassurance
The needy patient required constant attention

definitions: extremely wicked, villainous, or criminal in nature or purpose
examples: The villain's nefarious plot threatened the entire city
They uncovered his nefarious scheme to steal millions
Her nefarious activities finally caught up with her
The nefarious organization operated in complete secrecy

definitions: expressing or containing denial, prohibition, or refusal
harmful, undesirable, or unwelcome in effect or result
characterized by pessimism or lack of confidence
of a quantity or direction, less than zero
showing the absence of a particular substance or condition
examples: She gave a negative response to our proposal
The answer to your question is negative
The drug had negative effects on memory
Negative publicity damaged their reputation significantly
His negative attitude affected team morale badly
Don't be so negative about everything
The temperature dropped to negative ten degrees
Negative numbers appear below zero
The test came back negative for infection
X-rays showed negative results for fractures

definitions: not receiving proper care, maintenance, or attention
ignored, overlooked, or given insufficient attention
examples: The neglected garden was overgrown with weeds
Neglected buildings deteriorated beyond repair
She felt neglected by her busy parents
The neglected issue finally demanded urgent attention

definitions: failing to give proper care or attention to someone or something
examples: The neglectful parents lost custody of their children
His neglectful attitude toward maintenance caused problems
She was neglectful of her health for years
The neglectful landlord ignored tenant complaints

definitions: failing to take proper care in doing something; careless
examples: The negligent driver caused a serious accident
Negligent maintenance led to equipment failure
The company was negligent in safety procedures
Her negligent behavior resulted in patient harm

definitions: so small or unimportant as to be not worth considering
examples: The difference in price was negligible
Side effects from the medication are negligible
The negligible risk doesn't justify expensive precautions
Her contribution to the project was negligible

definitions: open to discussion or modification through negotiation
able to be transferred or assigned to another party
examples: The salary is negotiable depending on experience
All contract terms remain negotiable until signing
These negotiable securities can be easily traded
The check is negotiable by endorsement

definitions: situated next to or very near to something; adjacent
examples: The neighboring house caught fire from sparks
Neighboring countries signed a peace treaty
We borrowed sugar from our neighboring apartment
The neighboring towns share emergency services

definitions: new, recent, or revived in a modern form
examples: The neo baroque architecture attracted many tourists
Neo colonialism continues affecting developing nations
Their neo conservative policies sparked heated debate
The neo Gothic cathedral was completed recently

definitions: relating to the revival of classical styles in art and architecture
examples: The neoclassic building featured prominent columns
Neoclassic design emphasizes symmetry and proportion
His neoclassic sculptures resembled ancient Greek works
The neoclassic movement influenced European architecture

definitions: relating to the revival of classical styles in art, architecture, or literature
examples: The neoclassical facade impressed all visitors
Neoclassical economics dominates university curricula
The neoclassical mansion cost millions to restore
Her neoclassical poetry followed strict formal rules

definitions: relating to economic policies favoring free-market capitalism and reduced government spending
examples: Neoliberal policies reduced social welfare programs
The neoliberal agenda promoted privatization extensively
Critics blamed neoliberal economics for increasing inequality
The neoliberal reforms transformed the national economy

definitions: relating to the later Stone Age when farming and polished tools appeared
examples: The neolithic settlement dated back ten thousand years
Neolithic farmers first domesticated wheat and barley
The neolithic revolution transformed human society fundamentally
These neolithic tools show sophisticated craftsmanship

definitions: relating to newborn children, especially during their first month
examples: The neonatal unit provides specialized care for premature babies
Neonatal mortality rates have decreased significantly
She specialized in neonatal medicine at the hospital
The neonatal screening detected a rare condition

definitions: anxious, worried, or apprehensive about something
relating to the nerves or nervous system
easily agitated or alarmed; highly strung
examples: She felt nervous before her job interview
The nervous students awaited their exam results
The nervous system controls bodily functions
Nervous disorders require specialized medical treatment
The nervous horse shied at every sound
He's a nervous person who startles easily

definitions: situated in a cozy, sheltered, or partly hidden position
examples: The cottage nestled among the trees looked inviting
A nestled village lay hidden in the valley
The baby remained nestled in her mother's arms
The cat stayed nestled in its favorite blanket

definitions: remaining after all deductions of expenses, taxes, or losses
final or ultimate in effect or result
examples: His net income barely covered living expenses
The company reported net profits of millions
The net result was a complete disaster
Their net effect on the environment was positive

definitions: lower in position, especially beneath the earth's surface
examples: Ancient myths described the nether regions of hell
The nether world frightened medieval believers
The explosion damaged the building's nether floors
They explored the castle's nether chambers

definitions: remaining after all deductions; same as net but chiefly British
examples: The nett weight excludes packaging materials
Their nett earnings increased this quarter
Calculate the nett price after all discounts
The nett amount payable is shown below

definitions: covered or protected with netting or mesh material
caught, gained, or earned as profit or result
examples: The netted enclosure protected plants from birds
Netted windows kept mosquitoes outside effectively
The scheme netted huge profits for investors
Her performance netted critical acclaim
